commits.message: Adding README links pointing to learning resources (#3975)

Doc dmaier quickstarts (#3985)

* Removed the document db quick start guide from the RediSearch repo because it was moved up in the hierarchy

* Moved the vector database quick start guide up in the hierarchy

issue.title: [BUG] Redis Search isn't working when number of JSON document crosses 8000
issue.body: **Describe the bug** I created total of 8820 JSON documents. Search doesn't work when I search for "Order" search key. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior: I created total of 8820 JSON documents as given in this file. [Bug.txt](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/files/13051138/Bug.txt) Then I created index as follows: ```shell FT.CREATE idx:custom_search ON JSON PREFIX 1 "custom_search:" SCHEMA $.entityId as entityId NUMERIC SORTABLE $.entityIdString as entityIdString TEXT $.entityType AS entityType TEXT SORTABLE $.resourceType AS resourceType TAG $.resourceValue AS resourceValue NUMERIC $.name AS name TEXT SORTABLE $.escapedName AS escapedName TEXT $.createdAt as createdAt NUMERIC SORTABLE $.updatedAt as updatedAt NUMERIC SORTABLE ``` Then I queried 2 records using JSON.GET: ```shell 127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.GET custom_search:table_order:11989 "{\"entityId\":11989,\"entityIdString\":\"11989\",\"entityType\":\"DINE_IN\",\"name\":\"NY_Order_Bidder_PG\",\"escapedName\":\"NY_Order_Bidder_PG\",\"resourceType\":\"CUSTOMER\",\"resourceValue\":10642,\"createdAt\":1663007400,\"updatedAt\":1693333800,\"metaData\":{\"hierarchy\":{}}}" 127.0.0.1:6379> JSON.GET custom_search:table_order:11990 "{\"entityId\":11990,\"entityIdString\":\"11990\",\"entityType\":\"DINE_IN\",\"name\":\"NY_Order_Bidder_NON-PG\",\"escapedName\":\"NY_Order_Bidder_NON\\\\-PG\",\"resourceType\":\"CUSTOMER\",\"resourceValue\":10642,\"createdAt\":1663007400,\"updatedAt\":1692297000,\"metaData\":{\"hierarchy\":{}}}" ``` I was able to get results for above two JSON documents. But when I search for `Order`, I get zero matching results. ```shell 127.0.0.1:6379> FT.SEARCH idx:custom_search " ( ( @entityIdString:(Order) | @entityIdString:(Order*) | @entityIdString:(*Order) | @entityIdString:(*Order*) ) | ( @escapedName:(Order) | @escapedName:(Order*) | @escapedName:(*Order) | @escapedName:(*Order*) ) ) @resourceType:{CUSTOMER} @resourceValue:[10642 10642]" 1) (integer) 0 ``` **Expected behavior** I expect below two JSON documents in the result of above search. 1. custom_search:table_order:11989 2. custom_search:table_order:11990 There are high chances of you reproducing this issue if you can create all 8820 records given in attached file Bug.txt **Screenshots** **Environment (please complete the following information):** - CPU model: - redis_version:7.2.0 - redis search version: [v2.8.4](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/releases/tag/v2.8.4) - os:Linux 5.15.128-1 x86_64; arch_bits:64 **Additional context** Add any other context about the problem here.

comment.body:
@raz-mon 
Let me create a script for you to create all database in your environment.

issue.title: Redisearch fails to compile on alpine:3.17 docker image
issue.body:
I'm trying to compile from source the Redisearch module and then load it to latest Redis-alpine (7.0.5 hich runs on alpine 3.17) by using multi stage docker build.

When trying to use alpine:3.17 the build fails (attaching dockerfile bellow):
```
FROM alpine:3.17 as modules-builder

# pre-installation
RUN apk update && apk upgrade && mkdir -p /usr/lib/redis/modules \
&& apk add git bash make musl-dev clang-libs clang-dev llvm cargo rust openssh perl coreutils gcc linux-headers g++ cmake py3-numpy py3-scipy


# build RediSearch (sed is used to adapt installation to alpine)
RUN git clone --recursive https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch.git && cd RediSearch \
&& sed 's/self.install("lcov")/print("hello")/g' ./sbin/system-setup.py > system-setup-1.py \
&& sed 's/self.install("lcov-git", aur=True)/print("hello")/g' system-setup-1.py > system-setup.py \
&& mv system-setup.py ./sbin/system-setup.py \
&& chmod +x ./sbin/system-setup.py \
&& rm -r ./system-setup-1.py \
&& sed 's/u_int64_t/unsigned long long/g' ./deps/VectorSimilarity/src/VecSim/info_iterator.h > info_iterator_1.h \
&& sed 's/int64_t/long long/g' info_iterator_1.h > info_iterator.h \
&& mv info_iterator.h ./deps/VectorSimilarity/src/VecSim/info_iterator.h \
&& chmod +x ./deps/VectorSimilarity/src/VecSim/info_iterator.h \
&& rm -r ./info_iterator_1.h \
&& sed '/#define calloc(count, size) RedisModule_Calloc(count, size)/d' ./deps/rmutil/alloc.h > alloc_1.h \
&& sed '/#define free(ptr) RedisModule_Free(ptr)/d' alloc_1.h > alloc.h \
&& mv alloc.h ./deps/rmutil/alloc.h \
&& chmod +x ./deps/rmutil/alloc.h \
&& rm -r ./alloc_1.h \
&& sed '/RedisModule_Calloc = calloc;/d' ./deps/rmutil/alloc.c > alloc_1.c \
&& sed '/RedisModule_Free = free;/d' alloc_1.c > alloc.c \
&& mv alloc.c ./deps/rmutil/alloc.c \
&& chmod +x ./deps/rmutil/alloc.c \
&& make setup \
&& apk del cmake && apk add cmake \
&& make build \
&& mv ./bin/linux-x64-release/search/redisearch.so /usr/lib/redis/modules


# build RedisJSON (sed is used to adapt installation to alpine)
RUN git clone --recursive https://github.com/RedisJSON/RedisJSON.git && cd RedisJSON \
&& sed 's/self.install("lcov")/print("hello")/g' ./sbin/system-setup.py > system-setup-1.py \
&& sed 's/self.install("lcov-git", aur=True)/print("hello")/g' system-setup-1.py > system-setup.py \
&& mv system-setup.py ./sbin/system-setup.py \
&& chmod +x ./sbin/system-setup.py \
&& rm -r ./system-setup-1.py \
&& cd ./deps/readies \
&& git submodule update --init \
&& cd - \
&& ./deps/readies/bin/getupdates \
&& ./deps/readies/bin/getpy3 \
&& ./sbin/system-setup.py \
&& make build SHOW=1 \
&& mv ./bin/linux-x64-release/rejson.so /usr/lib/redis/modules

FROM redis:7-alpine

RUN apk add --no-cache libgcc

COPY --from=modules-builder /usr/lib/redis/modules/* /usr/lib/redis/modules/

ENTRYPOINT ["redis-server"]
CMD ["--loadmodule", "/usr/lib/redis/modules/rejson.so", "--loadmodule", "/usr/lib/redis/modules/redisearch.so"]
```

But when trying to do the same with alpine 3.16 everything works just fine (it's the same dockerfile, just with the builder image changed):
```
FROM alpine:3.16 as modules-builder

# pre-installation
RUN apk update && apk upgrade && mkdir -p /usr/lib/redis/modules \
&& apk add git bash make musl-dev clang-libs clang-dev llvm cargo rust openssh perl coreutils gcc linux-headers g++ cmake py3-numpy py3-scipy


# build RediSearch (sed is used to adapt installation to alpine)
RUN git clone --recursive https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch.git && cd RediSearch \
&& sed 's/self.install("lcov")/print("hello")/g' ./sbin/system-setup.py > system-setup-1.py \
&& sed 's/self.install("lcov-git", aur=True)/print("hello")/g' system-setup-1.py > system-setup.py \
&& mv system-setup.py ./sbin/system-setup.py \
&& chmod +x ./sbin/system-setup.py \
&& rm -r ./system-setup-1.py \
&& sed 's/u_int64_t/unsigned long long/g' ./deps/VectorSimilarity/src/VecSim/info_iterator.h > info_iterator_1.h \
&& sed 's/int64_t/long long/g' info_iterator_1.h > info_iterator.h \
&& mv info_iterator.h ./deps/VectorSimilarity/src/VecSim/info_iterator.h \
&& chmod +x ./deps/VectorSimilarity/src/VecSim/info_iterator.h \
&& rm -r ./info_iterator_1.h \
&& sed '/#define calloc(count, size) RedisModule_Calloc(count, size)/d' ./deps/rmutil/alloc.h > alloc_1.h \
&& sed '/#define free(ptr) RedisModule_Free(ptr)/d' alloc_1.h > alloc.h \
&& mv alloc.h ./deps/rmutil/alloc.h \
&& chmod +x ./deps/rmutil/alloc.h \
&& rm -r ./alloc_1.h \
&& sed '/RedisModule_Calloc = calloc;/d' ./deps/rmutil/alloc.c > alloc_1.c \
&& sed '/RedisModule_Free = free;/d' alloc_1.c > alloc.c \
&& mv alloc.c ./deps/rmutil/alloc.c \
&& chmod +x ./deps/rmutil/alloc.c \
&& make setup \
&& apk del cmake && apk add cmake \
&& make build \
&& mv ./bin/linux-x64-release/search/redisearch.so /usr/lib/redis/modules


# build RedisJSON (sed is used to adapt installation to alpine)
RUN git clone --recursive https://github.com/RedisJSON/RedisJSON.git && cd RedisJSON \
&& sed 's/self.install("lcov")/print("hello")/g' ./sbin/system-setup.py > system-setup-1.py \
&& sed 's/self.install("lcov-git", aur=True)/print("hello")/g' system-setup-1.py > system-setup.py \
&& mv system-setup.py ./sbin/system-setup.py \
&& chmod +x ./sbin/system-setup.py \
&& rm -r ./system-setup-1.py \
&& cd ./deps/readies \
&& git submodule update --init \
&& cd - \
&& ./deps/readies/bin/getupdates \
&& ./deps/readies/bin/getpy3 \
&& ./sbin/system-setup.py \
&& make build SHOW=1 \
&& mv ./bin/linux-x64-release/rejson.so /usr/lib/redis/modules

FROM redis:7-alpine

RUN apk add --no-cache libgcc

COPY --from=modules-builder /usr/lib/redis/modules/* /usr/lib/redis/modules/

ENTRYPOINT ["redis-server"]
CMD ["--loadmodule", "/usr/lib/redis/modules/rejson.so", "--loadmodule", "/usr/lib/redis/modules/redisearch.so"]
```

The operation fails (in alpine 3.17) on the "make build" command (also the percentage finished by the "make build" command is inconsistent- sometimes it fails after 50% were done and sometimes after 70%).

In addition, I had to edit the python set up file (to remove the "lcov" tool installation which is not recognized by alpine) and also had to edit some other files as well (see the "sed" commands I used in order to make it work). Moreover, there are a lot of warnings during the make command due to referencing "sys/errno.h" instead of "errno.h".

issue.body:
I'm trying to compile from source the Redisearch module and then load it to latest Redis-alpine (7.0.5 hich runs on alpine 3.17) by using multi stage docker build.

When trying to use alpine:3.17 the build fails (attaching dockerfile bellow):
```

# pre-installation
RUN apk update && apk upgrade && mkdir -p /usr/lib/redis/modules \
&& apk add git bash make musl-dev clang-libs clang-dev llvm cargo rust openssh perl coreutils gcc linux-headers g++ cmake py3-numpy py3-scipy

&& sed 's/self.install("lcov")/print("hello")/g' ./sbin/system-setup.py > system-setup-1.py \

&& cd - \
&& ./deps/readies/bin/getupdates \
&& ./deps/readies/bin/getpy3 \
&& ./sbin/system-setup.py \
&& make build SHOW=1 \
&& mv ./bin/linux-x64-release/rejson.so /usr/lib/redis/modules

RUN apk add --no-cache libgcc

COPY --from=modules-builder /usr/lib/redis/modules/* /usr/lib/redis/modules/

ENTRYPOINT ["redis-server"]
CMD ["--loadmodule", "/usr/lib/redis/modules/rejson.so", "--loadmodule", "/usr/lib/redis/modules/redisearch.so"]
```

But when trying to do the same with alpine 3.16 everything works just fine (it's the same dockerfile, just with the builder image changed):
```
FROM alpine:3.16 as modules-builder

# pre-installation
RUN apk update && apk upgrade && mkdir -p /usr/lib/redis/modules \

&& chmod +x ./deps/rmutil/alloc.h \
&& rm -r ./alloc_1.h \
&& sed '/RedisModule_Calloc = calloc;/d' ./deps/rmutil/alloc.c > alloc_1.c \
&& sed '/RedisModule_Free = free;/d' alloc_1.c > alloc.c \
&& mv alloc.c ./deps/rmutil/alloc.c \
&& chmod +x ./deps/rmutil/alloc.c \
&& make setup \
&& apk del cmake && apk add cmake \
&& make build \
&& mv ./bin/linux-x64-release/search/redisearch.so /usr/lib/redis/modules


# build RedisJSON (sed is used to adapt installation to alpine)
RUN git clone --recursive https://github.com/RedisJSON/RedisJSON.git && cd RedisJSON \
&& sed 's/self.install("lcov")/print("hello")/g' ./sbin/system-setup.py > system-setup-1.py \
&& sed 's/self.install("lcov-git", aur=True)/print("hello")/g' system-setup-1.py > system-setup.py \
&& mv system-setup.py ./sbin/system-setup.py \
&& chmod +x ./sbin/system-setup.py \
&& rm -r ./system-setup-1.py \
&& cd ./deps/readies \
&& git submodule update --init \
&& cd - \
&& ./deps/readies/bin/getupdates \
&& ./deps/readies/bin/getpy3 \
&& ./sbin/system-setup.py \
&& make build SHOW=1 \
&& mv ./bin/linux-x64-release/rejson.so /usr/lib/redis/modules

RUN apk add --no-cache libgcc

COPY --from=modules-builder /usr/lib/redis/modules/* /usr/lib/redis/modules/

ENTRYPOINT ["redis-server"]
CMD ["--loadmodule", "/usr/lib/redis/modules/rejson.so", "--loadmodule", "/usr/lib/redis/modules/redisearch.so"]
```

The operation fails (in alpine 3.17) on the "make build" command (also the percentage finished by the "make build" command is inconsistent- sometimes it fails after 50% were done and sometimes after 70%).

In addition, I had to edit the python set up file (to remove the "lcov" tool installation which is not recognized by alpine) and also had to edit some other files as well (see the "sed" commands I used in order to make it work). Moreover, there are a lot of warnings during the make command due to referencing "sys/errno.h" instead of "errno.h".

comment.body: This issue was closed because it has been inactive for 7 days since being marked as stale.

issue.title: RediSearch cluster support for OSS
issue.body:
At the [Cluster support section](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch#cluster-support) it is stated that cluster support is only for Enterprise versions, which is not right.
Coordinator is available for RediSearch OSS versions too -> https://forum.redis.com/t/anything-to-do-to-get-redisearch-to-search-across-clusters/1943/2
README documentation should be updated for this.

Related issues:

- https://github.com/redis-stack/redis-stack-rpm/issues/6
- https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/issues/2970

comment.body: This issue is stale because it has been open for 60 days with no activity.

issue.title: MOD-5710: Restrict `FT.SEARCH` commands from using `LOAD`, `APPLY`
issue.body:
**Describe the changes in the pull request**

Currently, a command such as `ft.search idx * load 1 title apply upper(@title) as tU` will build a pipeline taking the `LOAD` and `APPLY` arguments into account, while the documentation does not mention such options.

Upon receiving an `FT.SEARCH` command accompanied with `LOAD`, `APPLY` arguments, an error should be raised in the form of “(error) option `LOAD` is mutually exclusive with simple (i.e. search) options“ (same for `APPLY`), as is raised for the `GROUPBY` argument.

comment.body: Does this addition change the size of the structure? If so, consider making `forCursor` and `depleted` flags and check if we need to limit the size of this member (if the compiler assigns it more than 8 bits).

pull_request.title: MOD-5209 - Coordinator timeout fix for `FT.AGGREGATE`
pull_request.body:
**Describe the changes in the pull request**

Today the coordinator doesn't get an indication of a timeout from the shards in `FT.AGGREGATE` commands, due to the hard-coded condition implying that we don't return timeouts from cursors (which the coordinator uses for communication with the shards). This PR adds a timeout check in the coordinator, such that any timeout in the shards will be caught in the coordinator as well, so that it can respond accordingly (with error). This is done by polling the timeout in the `rpnet` result-processor every time it pulls results from the shards (i.e., calls `getNextReply`).

A couple of things to notice:
1. The way the `sendChunk` function is written today, implies that once one result is returned with no errors, no errors will be replied to the client. This will be fixed later on, to be conditioned by the strictness of our response. This means that a timeout will not be raised to the client if some results already returned without a timeout.
2. More improvement should be made in our timeout catching. Today, we only poll timeouts in the reader (and now in the coordinator after pulling results from the shards). Thus, if we experience a timeout in the pipeline between these pollings and the response to the client, we miss it. We should probably poll for timeout in the sendChunk function, right before responding to the client.

Update:
We now take advantage of the `timeout` field we have in the `RedisSearchCtx`, such that we poll only this mutual `timespec`, rather than constructing `timespec`s for the different rp's throughout the pipeline.

Moreover, we stop pulling results from the shards once the coordinator experienced a timeout, and send a `CURSOR DEL` command to the shards instead of another `CURSOR READ`, in case there are more results in the shard-cursor. For this, we add the `timedOut` flag to the shared context (`MRIteratorCtx`), which is updated and read atomically.

**Main objects this PR modified**
1. `timespec startTime` removed from `QueryIterator`.
2. `timedOut` flag in `MRIteratorCtx`, indicating that the coordinator has experienced a timeout.

**Mark if applicable**

- [ ] This PR introduces API changes
- [ ] This PR introduces serialization changes

repo.name: RediSearch
repo.description: A query and indexing engine for Redis, providing secondary indexing, full-text search, vector similarity search and aggregations.

repo.name: RediSearch
repo.description: A query and indexing engine for Redis, providing secondary indexing, full-text search, vector similarity search and aggregations.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -995,16 +992,37 @@ def test_aggregate_timeout():
             pipeline = conn.pipeline(transaction=False)
     pipeline.execute()
 
-    # On coordinator, we currently get a single empty result on timeout,
-    # because all the shards timed out but the coordinator doesn't report it.
-    env.expect('FT.AGGREGATE', 'idx', '*',
-               'LOAD', '2', '@t1', '@__key',
-               'APPLY', '@t1 ^ @t1', 'AS', 't1exp',
-               'groupby', '2', '@t1', '@t1exp',
-                    'REDUCE', 'tolist', '1', '@__key', 'AS', 'keys',
-               'TIMEOUT', '1',
-        ).equal( ['Timeout limit was reached'] if not env.isCluster() else [1, ['t1', None, 't1exp', None, 'keys', []]])
+def aggregate_test(protocol=2):
+    if VALGRIND:
+        # You don't want to run this under valgrind, it will take forever
+        raise unittest.SkipTest("Skipping timeout test under valgrind")
+
+    if protocol == 2:
+        env = Env(moduleArgs='DEFAULT_DIALECT 2 ON_TIMEOUT FAIL')
+    elif protocol == 3:
+        env = Env(moduleArgs='DEFAULT_DIALECT 2 ON_TIMEOUT FAIL', protocol=3)
+    else:
+        env.skip()
comment.body:
```suggestion
    if VALGRIND:
        # You don't want to run this under valgrind, it will take forever
        raise unittest.SkipTest("Skipping timeout test under valgrind")
    elif protocol not in [2, 3]:
        # Unsupported protocol
        raise unittest.SkipTest("Unsupported protocol")

    env = Env(moduleArgs='DEFAULT_DIALECT 2 ON_TIMEOUT FAIL', protocol=protocol)
```

pull_request.title: MOD-5209 - Coordinator timeout fix for `FT.AGGREGATE`
pull_request.body:
**Describe the changes in the pull request**

Today the coordinator doesn't get an indication of a timeout from the shards in `FT.AGGREGATE` commands, due to the hard-coded condition implying that we don't return timeouts from cursors (which the coordinator uses for communication with the shards). This PR adds a timeout check in the coordinator, such that any timeout in the shards will be caught in the coordinator as well, so that it can respond accordingly (with error). This is done by polling the timeout in the `rpnet` result-processor every time it pulls results from the shards (i.e., calls `getNextReply`).

A couple of things to notice:
1. The way the `sendChunk` function is written today, implies that once one result is returned with no errors, no errors will be replied to the client. This will be fixed later on, to be conditioned by the strictness of our response. This means that a timeout will not be raised to the client if some results already returned without a timeout.
2. More improvement should be made in our timeout catching. Today, we only poll timeouts in the reader (and now in the coordinator after pulling results from the shards). Thus, if we experience a timeout in the pipeline between these pollings and the response to the client, we miss it. We should probably poll for timeout in the sendChunk function, right before responding to the client.

Update:
We now take advantage of the `timeout` field we have in the `RedisSearchCtx`, such that we poll only this mutual `timespec`, rather than constructing `timespec`s for the different rp's throughout the pipeline.

Moreover, we stop pulling results from the shards once the coordinator experienced a timeout, and send a `CURSOR DEL` command to the shards instead of another `CURSOR READ`, in case there are more results in the shard-cursor. For this, we add the `timedOut` flag to the shared context (`MRIteratorCtx`), which is updated and read atomically.

**Main objects this PR modified**
1. `timespec startTime` removed from `QueryIterator`.
2. `timedOut` flag in `MRIteratorCtx`, indicating that the coordinator has experienced a timeout.

**Mark if applicable**

- [ ] This PR introduces API changes

pull_request.title: MOD-5209 - Coordinator timeout fix for `FT.AGGREGATE`
pull_request.body:
**Describe the changes in the pull request**

Today the coordinator doesn't get an indication of a timeout from the shards in `FT.AGGREGATE` commands, due to the hard-coded condition implying that we don't return timeouts from cursors (which the coordinator uses for communication with the shards). This PR adds a timeout check in the coordinator, such that any timeout in the shards will be caught in the coordinator as well, so that it can respond accordingly (with error). This is done by polling the timeout in the `rpnet` result-processor every time it pulls results from the shards (i.e., calls `getNextReply`).

A couple of things to notice:
1. The way the `sendChunk` function is written today, implies that once one result is returned with no errors, no errors will be replied to the client. This will be fixed later on, to be conditioned by the strictness of our response. This means that a timeout will not be raised to the client if some results already returned without a timeout.
2. More improvement should be made in our timeout catching. Today, we only poll timeouts in the reader (and now in the coordinator after pulling results from the shards). Thus, if we experience a timeout in the pipeline between these pollings and the response to the client, we miss it. We should probably poll for timeout in the sendChunk function, right before responding to the client.

Update:
We now take advantage of the `timeout` field we have in the `RedisSearchCtx`, such that we poll only this mutual `timespec`, rather than constructing `timespec`s for the different rp's throughout the pipeline.

Moreover, we stop pulling results from the shards once the coordinator experienced a timeout, and send a `CURSOR DEL` command to the shards instead of another `CURSOR READ`, in case there are more results in the shard-cursor. For this, we add the `timedOut` flag to the shared context (`MRIteratorCtx`), which is updated and read atomically.

**Main objects this PR modified**
1. `timespec startTime` removed from `QueryIterator`.
2. `timedOut` flag in `MRIteratorCtx`, indicating that the coordinator has experienced a timeout.

**Mark if applicable**

- [ ] This PR introduces API changes
- [ ] This PR introduces serialization changes

     #   1. The language requested in the command.
     #   2. The scorer requested in the command.
     #   3. Parameters evaluation
+
+def test_timeout(env):
+    """Tests that timeouts are handled properly by the coordinator.
+    We check that the coordinator returns a timeout error when the timeout is
+    reached in the shards or in the coordinator itself.
+    """
+
+    SkipOnNonCluster(env)
+    conn = getConnectionByEnv(env)
+
+    # Create the index
+    env.expect('FT.CREATE', 'idx', 'SCHEMA', 'title', 'TEXT').ok()
+
+    # Populate the database with 1500 * nshards documents
+    n_docs = int(1500 * env.shardsCount)

+        conn.execute_command('HSET', i ,'t1', str(i))
+
+    # Set the timeout policy to fail upon experiencing a timeout
+    env.expect('_FT.CONFIG', 'SET', 'ON_TIMEOUT', 'FAIL').ok()

pull_request.title: MOD-5945: Fix bad comparison
pull_request.body:
Fix of a bad condition. Today we don't fail due to a check of the alias list in case the `INDEXSPEC_LOAD_NOALIAS` flag isn't on, but there is no good reason comparing the length of the strings (index and alias) instead of the strings, which is prone for error.

**Mark if applicable**

- [ ] This PR introduces API changes
- [ ] This PR introduces serialization changes

pull_request.title: MOD-5965: Return error upon timeout
pull_request.body:
Currently, in case we experience a timeout throughout pipeline execution, we may reply to the client with a simple string depicting the error message, instead of replying with an error (with that same error message).

This PR fixes this, so that we always return an error.

**Mark if applicable**

- [ ] This PR introduces API changes
- [ ] This PR introduces serialization changes
